revision.text:
[[Image:World map of submarine cables.png|300px|thumb|Global [[submarine communications cable|submarine cables]] in 2007]] [[Image:1901 Eastern Telegraph cables.png|300px|thumb|[[Eastern Telegraph]] cable network in 1901]] A '''global network''' is any [[communication network]] which spans the entire [[Earth]]. The term, as used in this article refers in a more restricted way to ''bidirectional'' communication networks, and to technology-based networks. Early networks such as [[international mail]] and unidirectional communication networks, such as [[radio network|radio]] and [[television network|television]], are described elsewhere.
The first global network was established using [[electrical telegraph]]y and global span was achieved in 1899. The [[public switched telephone network|telephony network]] was the second to achieve global status, in the 1950s. More recently, interconnected [[IP network]]s (principally the [[Internet]], with estimated 2.5 billion users worldwide in 2014 <ref>http://export.gov/northcarolina/build/groups/public/@eg_us_nc/documents/webcontent/komarketingpresentation065541.pdf</ref>), and the [[GSM]] [[mobile communication]] network (with over 6 billion worldwide users in 2014) form the largest global networks of all.
Setting up global networks requires immensely costly and lengthy efforts lasting for decades. Elaborate interconnections, [[Telephone exchange|switching]] and [[routing]] devices, laying out physical carriers of information, such as land and [[submarine communications cable|submarine cables]] and [[earth station]]s must be set in operation. In addition, international [[communication protocol]]s, legislation and agreements are involved.
Global networks might also refer to networks of individuals (such as [[Scientific collaboration network|scientists]]), communities (such as [[city network|cities]]) and organizations (such as [[Civil society#Global|civil organizations]]) worldwide which, for instance, might have formed for the management, mitigation and resolval of [[global issue]]s.
==Satellite global networks==
[[Communication satellite]]s are an important part of global networks. However, there are specific [[low Earth orbit]] (LEO) global [[satellite constellation]]s, such as [[Iridium satellite constellation|Iridium]], [[Globalstar]] and [[Orbcomm]], which are comprised by dozens of similar satellites which are put in orbit at regularly spaced positions and form a [[mesh network]], sometimes sending and receiving information directly among themselves. Using [[VSAT]] technology, [[satellite internet access]] has become possible.
==Mobile wireless networks==
It is estimated that 80% of the global mobile market uses the GSM standard, present in more than 212 countries and territories. Its [[wikt:ubiquity|ubiquity]] makes international [[roaming]] very common between mobile phone operators, enabling subscribers to use their phones in many parts of the world. In order to achieve this, these networks must be interconnected by way of [[peering]] arrangements, and therefore the GSM network is a truly global one.
==Network interconnection==
The telegraph and [[telex]] communication networks have been phased out, so [[interconnection]] among existing global networks arise at several points, such as between the voice [[telephony]] and digital [[data network]]s, and between these and satellite networks. Many applications run now on several networks, such as [[VoIP]] (voice over IP). [[Mobile communication]] (voice and data) networks are also intimately intertwinned, because the majority of 21st century [[cell phone]]s have both voice and data (internet navigation and [[email]]ing) capabilities.
Digital global networks require huge carrying capacity in the main [[internet backbone|backbone]]s. This is currently achieved by [[fiber optic cable]]s.
==Social and economic impact== The Canadian [[sociologist]] [[Marshall McLuhan]] was the first to forecast the huge impact of the matrix of global networks upon [[society]], coining the term [[global village (term)|global village]]. His work, however, related to radio and television networks, which are [[broadcast]] (unidirectional) networks, thus predating the much larger impact of the internet.<ref>Harasim, L. (Ed.) - [https://books.google.com/books?id=9RAnJzaiqvMC Global Networks: Computers and International Networks, 1993]</ref>
Global networks have revolutionized human communication several times. The first to do so was the electrical telegraph. Its impact was so large that it has been dubbed the [[Victorian Internet]]. It was expanded many times in its coverage with the advent of [[radiotelegraphy]], and with text messaging using [[telex]] machines.
The Internet and mobile communication networks have made possible entirely new forms of [[social interaction]], activities and organizing, thanks to its basic features such as widespread [[usability]] and access, and instant communication from any connected point to another. Thus, its [[Internet#Social impact|social impact]] has been, and still is, enormous. Finally, the impact on governance have been significant facilitating the emergence of 'transnational policy networks' <ref>Stone, Diane. Knowledge actors and transnational governance: The private-public policy nexus in the global agora. Palgrave Macmillan, 2013.</ref>
==See also== {{col div|colwidth=35em}} * [[History of telecommunication]] **[[History of the Internet]] **[[History of radio]] **[[History of television]] **[[History of the telephone]] **[[History of telegraphy]] * [[Mobile telecommunications]] * [[Computer networking]] * [[Communication protocol]] * [[Network architecture]] * [[Global network positioning]] * [[Telephony]] * [[Fiber optic cable]] * [[Telegraphy]] {{colend}}
==References== <references/>
{{Globalization|state=autocollapse}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Global Network}} [[Category:Communication]] [[Category:Computer networking]] [[Category:Satellites]] [[Category:Mobile telecommunications]] [[Category:World]] [[Category:Social networks]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Iraqis in the Netherlands |image = |population = 55,000 - 60,000 '''0.3% of the Dutch population''' |popplace = [[Amsterdam]], [[Den Haag]], [[Almelo]], [[Arnhem]], [[Enschede]] |langs = [[Dutch language|Dutch]], [[Iraqi Arabic]], [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]], [[South Azeri language|Turkmen]], [[Neo-Aramaic languages|Neo-Aramaic]] (incl. [[Mandaic language|Mandaic]]) |rels = Predominantly [[Islam]] (61 percent) and [[Christianity]] (29 percent)([[Syriac Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Catholic]]). |related = [[Arab]]s, [[Armenians]], [[Assyrian people|Assyrians]], [[Azerbaijani people|Azeris]], [[Iranian peoples|Iranians]], [[Mizrahi Jews|Mizrahim]], [[Turkish people|Turks]],
Some descendants [[Dutch people|Dutch]] }} There are over 50,000 '''Iraqis in the Netherlands''', including immigrants from Iraq and locally born people of Iraqi heritage, constiting 0.3% of the total population in the Netherlands. Some sources claim an estimation of 60,000 people of Iraqi descent living in the Netherlands.[http://www.jenniferhamm.com/profiles_iraqis.html Jennifer Hamm :: Freelance Journalist] The Iraqi community in the Netherlands is the 4th largest and has the highest percentage of qualified and professional people and artistes who have integrated well and have become useful members of the Dutch society.[http://www.safara.info/English/2.htm :: Safara.info :: Iraqi Embassy in the Hague ::] ==Migration history== The first wave of immigrants was in 1992, the data confirm duo this phenomenon, which rose gradually to reach a peak in 1998. 19.5 per cent of the interviewees from study report came in that year. While 13.5 per cent in 1999. However, numbers have decreased in 2003 and 2004, which was 1 per cent, and in 1992, the proportion was 2 per cent.{{cite web|url=https://www.nsv-sociologie-facta.nl/activiteiten/dvds2007/papers/The%20Iraqi%20Community%20in%20the%20Netherlands.doc |title=Study Report of the Iraqi Community in the Netherlands |accessdate=2008-02-14 |publisher=nsv-sociologie-facta.nl }} The Iraqi community in the Netherlands has increased from 8,000 in 1995 to approximately 40,000 in 2002. Apart from this group, there is an unknown number of Iraqis illegally staying in the Netherlands.[http://www.fas.org/irp/world/netherlands/aivd2002.pdf Iraqi migration to the Netherlands] The main motives of the Iraqi migration are political asylum seeking resulting previous conditions in Iraq regarding the nature of the former regime, and the circumstances of successive wars and the economic embargo which was imposed on Iraq. ==Demography== A recent study report, shows that two-thirds of the Iraqi community in the Netherlands are young and well qualified to work in the various fields of life. However, many of which are unemployed despite being well educated. The level of integration of the Iraqi community with the Dutch people is noticeably low. It amounts to a quarter out of the standards of social integration. The level of mastery of the Dutch language and of the participation in the social and political activities is quite low. The commitment to the mother culture with its Islamic, Arab and Iraqi references is quite high. Judging by gender of the Iraqi population, it has been assessed that 60 per cent are males and females account for 40 per cent. Most of the Iraqi community are younger age groups and qualify for the labor market, the age categories are between 26-35 and 36–45 years, they were 28 per cent for each category. This reflects the new age of the Iraqi community in the Netherlands, which also means that most members of this community are first generation. With regard to the marital status, the largest proportion of whom are married is at 58 per cent, this figure represents 53 per cent males and 68 per cent females. Due to a lot of Iraqi women coming to the Netherlands because of family reunification, whether married already or later. The (non or never married) was accounted for 25 per cent. There is a good proportion of inter-marriage between members of the Iraqi community in the Netherlands and Dutch or others. The proportion is 12.5 per cent with Dutch people, that was among 13 cases of Iraqi men with Dutch women and 4 cases of Iraqi women married from Dutch men. The rest is refers to some cases with foreigners. While the highest rate of marriage represents 81 per cent of the same country (Iraq). There is a high level of friendship relations between Iraqi immigrants and the Dutch people. There is no divergence for Iraqis in accordance with their religious background of both Muslims and Christians to build a friendship with the Dutch. Where equal ratio between them is 70 per cent for each part. While the proportion of the non-believers is 100 per cent, which reflects the overcome on some reservations expressed by some immigrants from religious background. {|class="wikitable" |+Population centers (2013) |- !city!!population!!city ratio |- |[[Amsterdam]] |2,800 | |- |[[The Hague]] |2,800 | |- |[[Rotterdam]] |2,100 | |- |[[Almere]] |1,800 | |- |[[Almelo]] |1,700 |2.3% |- |[[Arnhem]] |1,300 |1% |- |[[Utrecht]] |1,200 | |- |[[Enschede]] |1,200 | |- |[[Delft]] |1,100 |1.1% |- |[[Groningen]] |800 | |- |[[Eindhoven]] |700 | |- |[[Zwolle]] |700 | |- |[[Nijmegen]] |700 | |- |[[Hengelo]] |600 | |- |} {{citation needed|date=May 2012}} ==Education== The rate of education to the Iraqi community, whether men or women is high and over that with Moroccans, Surinamese and comparing with the Dutch people too. According to the study, the total holding higher degrees (High Institute, Bachelor's, Master's and Ph.D.) are 54 per cent. While the rest carry secondary school and below certificates. However, there was a low proportion of Iraqis who obtained diploma’s and certificates from the Netherlands. The proportion is 21 per cent for various academic levels. But the percentage is higher for a secondary certificate, it is not a high level compared with other graduates from Iraq who made up 69 per cent. That means that most holders of these certificates are younger ages in the community study, or second generation. ==Employment== There is a high rate of the unemployment among Iraqi immigrants, 40 per cent of whom are unemployed, compared with only 13 per cent who officially work and 12 per cent free work. Unemployment is also concentrated among people who are higher educated, especially university graduates, while lower percentage is among other educational levels. ==Language== There is a low percentage of Iraqis who use the Dutch language in their homes through their dealings with their children and parents. The proportion was only 17.5 per cent. Meanwhile, there is 47.5 per cent who do not use it at all. According to results of the study, the majority of interviewees (62 per cent) have impression that the Dutch language is (difficult). Compared with 30 per cent of them who felt that it is (reasonable to learn). While only 7 per cent said it is (easy). ==Notable people== * [[Hashim Mohammed Gafer]], Iraqi Politician and member of Iraqi COR * [[Salah Abdel-Razzaq]], Governor of Baghdad * [[Mohamed Al-Daradji]], film director * [[Mahmoud Jasim Al-najar]], author/poet * [[Wesam al-Delaema]], accused by the [[United States|US]] of conspiring to kill Americans in Iraq. * [[Farida Mohammad Ali]], singer * [[Hagal Amin]], film director[http://www.syrialive.net/Entertainment/archives/2003/music_news_mar03.htm Leisure & Entertainment - March 2003] * [[Dashni Murad]], singer of Kurdish origin * [[Essam Zaki]], fashion designer[http://www.essamzaki.com/ Iraqi-Dutch fashion designer][http://www.futuretvnetwork.com/projectfashion/ Future TV] * [[Nedim Kufi]], artist * [[Viola Haqi]], fashion model[http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/models/viola_haqi FMD - Profile of fashion model viola haqi] * [[Ciawar Khandan]], footballer * [[Osama Rashid]], footballer * [[Anmar Almubaraki]], footballer * [[Hawbir Mostafa]], footballer * [[Qassim Alsaedy]], artist * [[Laila Al-Zwaini]], author[http://www.asmasociety.org/wise/participants.html WISE] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524045551/http://asmasociety.org/wise/participants.html |date=2009-05-24 }} * [[Rodaan Al Galidi]], writer * [[Mariwan Kanie]], writer ==See also== *[[Demographics of the Netherlands]] *[[Arabs in the Netherlands]] ==External links== * [http://www.hammurabi.nl/ Hammurabi (The Iraqi Student Organization)] * [http://iraqdutch.com/ Iraq Dutch Group for Reconstruction and Development] * [http://www.irakesejongeren.nl Iraqi Youth Organization] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Ethnic groups in the Netherlands}} {{Iraqi diaspora}} [[Category:Arabs in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Dutch society| ]] [[Category:Dutch people of Iraqi descent| ]] [[Category:Iraqi emigrants to the Netherlands| ]] [[Category:Middle Eastern diaspora in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Iraqi diaspora|Dutch]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in the Netherlands]]

{{Multiple issues| {{POV|date=May 2016}} {{BLP sources|date=May 2016}} }} {{Infobox person | image = John M Dougan Walkking forest, photo by Olga Leonova.jpg{{!}}border | alt = | caption = John Mark Dougan (07 October 2016) | birth_name = John Mark Dougan | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1976|12|15|mf=yes}} | birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Wilmington, Delaware]], U.S.}} | residence = [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] | nationality = [[American people|American]] | education = | occupation = Chief Executive Officer | employer = Badger Aero | known_for = Fleeing to Moscow, Russia to evade FBI | criminal_charge = Unauthorised Access of a Computer ([[Security hacker|Hacking]]) | website = http://www.johnmark.ru }}
'''John Dougan''' ({{lang-ru|Джон Марк Дуган}}) is a former police officer who fled the [[United States]] for [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] to obtain [[political asylum]] in 2016. Dougan was running a website that had been critical of Ric Bradshaw, the [[sheriff]] of [[Palm Beach County, Florida]]. Dougan fled after his home was raided by law enforcement authorities on March 14, 2016.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Swisher |first1=Skyler |title=Critic of Palm Beach County sheriff says FBI searched his home in probe of computer hack |url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/local/palm-beach/fl-palm-fbi-hack-raid-20160314-story.html |accessdate=5 October 2018 |publisher=Sun Sentinel |date=14 March 2016}}</ref>
Dougan stated that after the raid on his home, the FBI was following him and his family, so he decided to flee the country. He wore various disguises and snuck into Canada to avoid U.S. Customs, which he suspected had him on a [[no-fly list]]. Dougan then took a flight from [[Toronto]] to [[Istanbul]], and boarded another flight to his final destination, Moscow, Russia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ntv.ru/novosti/1622358/|title="Достало!": американский полицейский объяснил свое желание переехать в Россию|website=НТВ|language=Russian|trans-title="Enough!": American policeman explained his desire to move to Russia|access-date=2016-05-08}}</ref>
In 2009, Dougan started his website, PBSOtalk.org, and began making public records requests based on tips from readers and anonymous posters on the website. In 2012, he received information and public records, that the elected Sheriff of Palm Beach County was using taxpayer money to take campaign contributors, some with ties to organized crime. After filing a complaint with the Florida Commission on Ethics, the Sheriff was cleared "because he didn't know it was a violation of the law." However, the Commission stated the money he used to take those people to dinner was "inconsistent with the proper performance of his public duties".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/palm-beach-county-sheriff-ric-bradshaw-chided-for-/nN2sx/|title=Palm Beach County Sheriff Ric Bradshaw chided for using tax money|work= [[The Palm Beach Post]] |access-date=2016-05-10}}</ref>
Shortly after the ethics complaint was filed, the Chief Deputy of Palm Beach County filed a lawsuit against Dougan <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/sheriffs-office-second-in-command-files-defamation/nPKbn/|title=Sheriff's Office second-in-command files defamation lawsuit|work= The Palm Beach Post|access-date=2016-05-10}}</ref> after the Sheriff's office tried unsuccessfully to purchase the web site from Dougan.
In what was billed as a digital election-day dirty trick the night before the November 2012 elections,<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/local-govt-politics/aaronson-denies-sending-email-blasting-bradshaw-in/nRBJ9/|title=Aaronson seeks investigation into faux email blasting Bradshaw...|work= The Palm Beach Post|access-date=2016-05-10}}</ref> an email was sent out to the A-list of voters in Palm Beach County from BurtAaronson.com, a domain owned by Dougan. The email stated that BurtAaronson.com no longer endorsed the Sheriff as a candidate and instead endorsed the other candidate in the race. The real Burt Aaronson, who was, at the time, a county commissioner, stated he was outraged and had no knowledge of the email. He accused Dougan of identity theft, and attempted to have Dougan arrested. The Palm Beach County State Attorney's office, however, determined since Dougan owned the domain, he was legally justified in using it, however, called the email "outrageous conduct," further saying that laws have not kept up with mischief that can be wreaked on the Internet.<ref name=":0" />
In 2015, Dougan obtained and posted a collection of audio recordings of a Palm Beach County detective speaking to an unidentified woman. The recordings revealed targeted retaliations and investigations against the Sheriff's political enemies, including Dougan, that speak critically of the Sheriff.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/crime-law/deputy-who-said-he-went-after-bradshaws-enemies-in/nnRny/|title=Deputy who said he went after Bradshaw's enemies investigated|work= The Palm Beach Post|access-date=2016-05-10}}</ref> The FBI and Palm Beach County raid on Dougan's home was motivated by the posting of these audio files, which was deemed to be wiretapping. The other reason listed on the warrant was for suspected hacking, and posting of names, of thousands of names, addresses and phone numbers of law enforcement officers, judges and FBI agents, though the property appraiser claimed nothing was ever hacked.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mypalmbeachpost.com/news/news/crime-law/pbso-investigating-release-of-confidential-law-enf/nqRHw/|title=PBSO investigating release of confidential law enforcement addresses|last=Writer|first=By Lawrence Mower - Palm Beach Post Staff|website=www.mypalmbeachpost.com|access-date=2016-05-10}}</ref> Dougan claimed it was merely a reason to seize his computers and attempt to locate the sources of his information as well as to shut down his web site.
==2016 Election Claims== During the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. Presidential elections]], Dougan falsely claimed to have played a role in the leak of emails from the Democratic National Committee and the Hillary Clinton campaign.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Poulsen |first1=Kevin |title=Fugitive Cop Says He’s Behind the DNC Leaks. It’s His Latest Hoax. |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/fugitive-cop-says-hes-behind-the-dnc-leaks-its-his-latest-hoax |accessdate=5 October 2018 |publisher=The Daily Beast |date=12 July 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://PBSOTalk.ru PBSOTalk.ru] * [http://johnmark.ru John Mark Dougan's personal website] * [https://rtd.rt.com/films/breaking-bad-wolf/ Breaking Bad Wolf: Why American cop and whistleblower Mark Dougan turned to Russia for sanctuary—RTD Documentary Channel Films] * [https://badvolf.com/store/badvolf-the-book-by-john-mark-dougan.html ''Badvolf'', John Mark Dougan's book.]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dougan, John Mark}} [[Category:American exiles]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted by the United States]] [[Category:People from Palm Beach County, Florida]] [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Privacy activists]] [[Category:American human rights activists]] [[Category:Refugees in Russia]]

{{Infobox school | name =John XIII College, Cochabamba | native_name = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = Juan23Bolivia.png | motto = Not students who work but workers who study | type = [[Jesuit]], [[Catholic church|Catholic]] | status = | gender = Coeducational | denomination = | affiliation = | affiliations = <!-- Localización --> | administrator = | assst_admin = |rector = Edgar Dávalos, SJ<ref>[http://www.jesuitas.org.bo/obras/colegio-juan-xxiii/ Specs from Bolivia Jesuits. Retrieved 17 December 2016.]</ref> | director =Nercy Mamani | president = | principal = | asst principal = | dean = | headmaster = | staff = | teaching_staff = | enrollment = 2,900 | grades = primary 6 to 4th secondary | tuition = | established = {{Start date and age| 1966 }}<ref name=decom>[http://www.infodecom.net/nacionales/la-paz/item/12109-fe-y-alegria-a-50-anos-de-su-creacion 50th anniversary. Retrieved 17 December 2016.]</ref> | streetaddress = | city = [[Cochabamba]], [[Bolivia]] | state = | province = | country = | accreditation = | campus = | colors = | athletics = | nickname = | mascot = | yearbook = |publication = | newspaper = | national_ranking = | free_label1 = Nickname | free_text1 =Juancho | free_label2 = |free_text2 = | free_label3 = | free_text3 = | website = [http://centroderecursos.alboan.org/ebooks/0000/0728/6_FyA_CAS.pdf John XIII ] | picture = | picture_caption = }}
'''John XIII College, Cochabamba''', [[Bolivia]], founded by the [[Jesuit|Jesuits]] in 1966, is a middle and high school that follows a work-study model. Most of its students are from low-income families in mining towns.
== Educational model == Juan XXIII College is administered by the [[Society of Jesus]] and covers the sixth year of primary through four years of secondary school. It now follows the [[Fe y Alegría]] school model which originated in [[Venezuela]] in 1955. It caters to the poor, drawing its students from a wide area. The [[Inter-American Development Bank]] assisted in funding the extension of this model to more schools in Bolivia. John XIII graduates contributed to this effort.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://centroderecursos.alboan.org/ebooks/0000/0728/6_FyA_CAS.pdf|title=ALBOAN Aid Center |last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
John XIII took on this model in its fifth year of operation, in 1971, when Alfonso Pedrajas {"Pica") helped transform it, introducing to Bolivia a more socialist approach that creates a sense of solidarity and interdependence. He used the slogan: "Not students who work but workers who study."
In 1976 Pica began admitting girls to the boarding school. He also increased the intake from outlying provinces and mining towns. Work is included in the curriculum and trade union leader [[Workers' Vanguard Party|Filemon Escóbar]] spent a time teaching at John XIII.
In 1986, during a Latin American Congress of Fe y Alegría in [[Cochabamba]], John XXIII was named as a [[Latin America]]<nowiki/>n model of education for production. The school along with its [[utopia]]<nowiki/>n vision have been described as "little new Bolivia".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eju.tv/2009/03/alfonso-pedrajas/|title=Alfonso Pedrajas|website=eju.tv|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref> Graduates of John XIII and of the Jesuit [[Colegio San Calixto, La Paz]], while serving as Jesuit volunteers in Bolivia, have brought about growth of this educational model in Jesuit schools. Elements of the school model include parent participation, pay in kind for school expenses, use of peasant educators, and physical labor (fetching firewood and water and tending an orchard). Evening activities include story reading and sharing personal histories. The model spread to Rodeo (1985),<ref>[http://chile.americasolidaria.org/informate/finalizamos-proyecto-de-rodeo-y-tiraque-en-bolivia/ School in Rodeo, Bolivia. Retrieved 17 December 2016.]</ref> Pampa (1987), and Churicana (1988).<ref>[http://www.feyalegria.org/archivos/file/PromocionSocialEnLasYachayWasisDeBolivia_AidaFerreyra.pdf Fe y Alegria Bolivia archives. Retrieved 17 December 2016.]</ref>
Colegio Juan XXIII uses a system of student self-government, with a student prime minister and other ministers, to enable students to experience democracy and to expand their social skills.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.entwicklung.at/en/themes/projects/detail-en/project/show/colegio-juan-xxiii-cochabambabolivien-und-salzburger-schulen-im-nord-sued-dialog/|title=Colegio Juan XXIII Cochabamba/Bolivien und Salzburger Schulen im Nord-Süd-Dialog- Austrian Development Agency|website=www.entwicklung.at|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8Kc9xQ7-whQC&pg=PA135&lpg=PA135&dq=Colegio+Juan+XXIII,+Cochabamba&source=bl&ots=rTU2nNPQVn&sig=F0aHTo1-ReZwH4_ob1SJMuoxzmw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJ_NKXxfnQAhVK4CYKHVLHBPc4FBDoAQgmMAI#v=onepage&q=Colegio%20Juan%20XXIII,%20Cochabamba&f=false|title="El evangelio es la encarnación de los derechos humanos--": una respuesta a los ataques del MAS : la Iglesia Católica y su lucha por la recuperación de la democracia|date=2011-01-01|publisher=Plural editores|isbn=9789995413750|language=es}}</ref>
Simon Education Foundation in 2007 initiated a Pilot Center for Technology Education in Cochabamba at John XIII that has served as a model for six other such centers in Bolivia; their first effort was training electricians.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.simon.es/images/stories/simon/empresa/Simon|title=Simon Education Foundation|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=17 December 2016}}</ref>
Facilities include a coliseum, library, audio-visual rooms, two special education classrooms (serving 200 children with disabilities), and 24 ordinary classrooms.<ref name="decom" />
==Alumni association== On 19 November 1991 the National Association of Alumni of John XXIII College was formed, with working groups like "CEADES Health and Environment" which works toward improving health and environmental conditions, contributing to Bolivia's social development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ceadesbolivia.org/institucion.aspx|title=CEADES :: Quienes Somos|website=www.ceadesbolivia.org|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://promoleonardoboff1985.blogspot.com/2011_03_01_archive.html|title=El juancho: ayer, hoy y posiblemente mañana|last=Antelo|first=Omar Quiroga|date=2011-03-15|website=Promoción Leonardo Boff 1985|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref>
==See also== *[http://www.worldcat.org/title/colegio-juan-xxiii-cochabamba/oclc/22011175 Matías Preiswerk. ''The Colegio Juan XXIII: Cochabamba''. La Paz, Bolivia: Center for Popular Theology, 1988, 121 pp.] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Coord|17|28|31.79|S|66|20|29.55|W|display=title}} [[Category:Catholic schools in South America]] [[Category:Schools in Bolivia]] [[Category:Jesuit secondary schools]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1966]] [[Category:Jesuit development centres]] [[Category:Environmentalism]] [[Category:Poverty-related organizations]] [[Category:Community-building organizations]]

[[Image:Vojvodina languages2011.png|thumb|250px|Language map of Vojvodina based on the 2011 municipality data]] '''Languages''' spoken in the [[Serbia]]n province of '''[[Vojvodina]]''' include [[South Slavic languages]] ([[Serbian language|Serbian]], [[Croatian language|Croatian]], [[Bunjevac language|Bunjevac]], [[Šokac language|Šokac]], [[Macedonian language|Macedonian]], [[Slovenian language|Slovenian]], [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]]), [[West Slavic languages]] ([[Slovak language|Slovak]], [[Polish language|Polish]], and [[Czech language|Czech]]), [[East Slavic languages]] ([[Rusyn language|Rusyn]], [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]], [[Russian language|Russian]]), [[Hungarian language]], [[Romanian language]], [[German language]], [[Romani language]], [[Albanian language]], [[Chinese language]], etc.
==Historical overview==
It is unknown which languages were spoken in the territory of present-day Vojvodina in [[paleolithic]] and [[neolithic]] times. First speakers of [[Indo-European languages]] arrived here in 4200 BC and since the first written traces about this region appeared, there are records about speakers of various Indo-European languages that lived in this area, including speakers of [[Thracian languages|Thracian]], [[Illyrian languages|Illyrian]], [[Celtic languages|Celtic]], [[Iranian languages|Iranian]] and [[Italic languages|Italic]] branches of Indo-European language family. The decline and fall of the [[Roman Empire]] brought to this area speakers of [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] and [[Germanic languages|Germanic]] languages as well. Speakers of [[South Slavic languages]] settled in the area in the 6th century, while speakers of [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] appeared in the 9th century. [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] conquest of the region in the 16th century brought to this area speakers of [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Romani language|Romani]], and other languages, while [[Habsburg Monarchy|Habsburg]] conquest in the end of the 17th and first half of the 18th century brought here the speakers of [[German language|German]], [[Slovak language|Slovak]], [[Pannonian Rusyn language|Rusyn]], [[Czech language|Czech]], [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] and other languages. In recent years, there is an increasing number of speakers of [[Chinese language]] as well.
===2011 census===
According to the 2011 census, main languages spoken in Vojvodina were: *[[Serbian language|Serbian]]: 1,485,791 (76.91%) *[[Hungarian language|Hungarian]]: 241,164 (12.48%) *[[Slovak language|Slovak]]: 47,760 (2.47%) *[[Romani language|Romani]]: 27,430 (1.42%) *[[Romanian language|Romanian]]: 24,133 (1.25%) *[[Croatian language|Croatian]]: 14,576 (0.75%) *[[Pannonian Rusyn language|Rusyn]]: 11,154 (0.58%)
==Usage of minority languages== [[Image:Novi Sad mayor office.jpg|thumb|150px|Plaque in front of Mayor's office written in four official languages used in the City of Novi Sad: ([[Serbian language|Serbian]], [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], [[Slovak language|Slovak]], and [[Pannonian Rusyn language|Rusyn]])]] Besides [[Serbian language|Serbian]], which is the official language in the whole country, there are five regional languages in the official use by the provincial administration in Vojvodina: [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], [[Romanian language|Romanian]], [[Slovak language|Slovak]], [[Pannonian Rusyn language|Rusyn]], and [[Croatian language|Croatian]]. The Serbian language is used in all municipality governments, while minority languages are used in selected municipality governments. The Serbian language with [[Cyrillic script]] is in official use in all 45 municipalities of Vojvodina, while Serbian [[Latin script]] is in official use in only 23 of 45 municipalities. The Hungarian language is in official use in 29 municipalities, Slovak in 12, Romanian in 9, Rusyn in 6, and Croatian and Czech in 1 municipality each (however, the Czech language is not official at provincial level).
[[Radio Television of Vojvodina]], the public broadcaster in the province, broadcasts programme in 10 languages: Serbian, Hungarian, Slovak, Rusyn, Romanian, Bunjevac, Ukrainian, Romani, Croatian, and Macedonian. Certain TV shows are also translated into [[Sign language]].
==Maps== <gallery class=> Image:Linguistic map of Vojvodina, Serbia (based on 1910 census).png|Language map of Vojvodina - settlements data (1910 census) Image:Vojvodina languages 1910.png|Language map of Vojvodina - municipality data (1910 census) Image:Vojvodina languages1921.png|Language map of Vojvodina (1921 census) Image:Vojvodina languages1931.png|Language map of Vojvodina (1931 census) Image:Vojvodina languages2002.png|Language map of Vojvodina (2002 census) Image:Vojvodina serbian map.png|Official usage of Serbian language and its scripts in Vojvodina Image:Vojvodina hungarian map.png|Official usage of Hungarian language in Vojvodina Image:Vojvodina slovak map.png|Official usage of Slovak language in Vojvodina Image:Vojvodina romanian map.png|Official usage of Romanian language in Vojvodina Image:Vojvodina rusyn croatian czech map.png|Official usage of Rusyn, Croatian, and Czech language in Vojvodina </gallery>
